description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Ministry of National Security informs public that it is prepared to take necessary action against persons if necessary, for the maintenance of public order. With regards to reckless statements being made on social media, the relevant authority will be reviewing our current laws to determine if persons can be prosecuted for making uniformed, irresponsible statements.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 25 Mar 20, MOH advises population of alleged fake news post and authorized used of the official letterhead of the MOH. For general information specific to Trinidad and Tobago and on Covid-19, public are advised to visit the list of pages from MOH and Ministry of communication.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 28 Mar 20, MOH advises public about criminals masquerading as public heatlh employees and requesting access to homes, to alledgedly take body temperature readings, as part of the natonal COVID-19 response. 
Public are advised that while the overall management of the spread of COVID-19 does not include home visits by public health employees, officials are required to have official MHO or Regional Health Authority photo identification clearly displayed at all times and presented to resident upon request. 
Public should immediately terminiate further contanct and contact the police should individual refused to display or present their identification. They may call the relevant public health unit to confirm the identity.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Trinidad and Tobago imposes a 14 day travel restriction for persons departing China. All people who have been to China over the past two weeks have to spend a 14 day incubation period in a non-risk country before entering T&T again.

description: Trinidad and Tobago imposes a 14 day travel restrictions for persons departing China from January 30 onwards. All people presently living or having visited China, will be forced to spend two weeks in a non-risk country to ensure that they develop no symptoms to be granted entry again.

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on 9 February that travel restrictions remain in place and no end date can be provided at this point. The Minister of Health advises TT nationals in China to remain there whether they are symptomatic or not, the reason provided being that it would be riskier for them to fly back on full planes and pass through crowded airports than to stay put. It is stated that those who want to return will not be refused entry into the country, but will be put under self-isolation. UPDATE: Travel restrictions remain and no end date can be specified. Advice provided to TT nationals in China to remain there.
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 21 Dec 20, MOH Trinidad and Tobago advises on new protocols relating to a new strain of the Covid-19 virus in the UK. All persons coming from the UK into Trinidad and Tobago (where the time between the date of departure and the date of arrival into Trinidad and Tobago is 14 days or less):
1. A negative PCR test within 72 hours prior to travelling (also necessary for all persons entering Trinidad and Tobago at this time);
2. A mandatory 14-day quarantine period to be spent in a state or state supervised facility.
The new protocol deviates from the current quarantine period to be served by persons entering the country from other high-risk countries which presently remains, 7 days in state or state supervised quarantine followed by 7 days home quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description:
On 4 April 20,  MOH Trinidad and Tobago advises the general population that once they are out in public, cloth masks (including handmade masks) should be used as part of the full range of personal protection measures that should be adopted to reduce the spread of COVID-19. 
As previously stated, surgical masks and N95 masks should be left for used by health care workers.

description: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago informs public that, as of 25 February 2020, tests on the individual who arrived from China to Tobago on 21 February have returned negative for COVID-19 and the individual will remain in quarantine for a total of 14 days with daily monitoring by health officials. It confirms that there are currently no cases of COVID-19 in Trinidad and Tobago. UPDATE: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago informs public that there are currently no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the country.

As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago informs public that, as of 25 February 2020, tests on the individual who arrived from China to Tobago on 21 February have returned negative for COVID-19 and the individual will remain in quarantine for a total of 14 days with daily monitoring by health officials. It confirms that there are currently no cases of COVID-19 in Trinidad and Tobago. UPDATE: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago informs public that there are currently no confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the country.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On 4 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Minister of Health provides advice to the public to use 'common sense measures' to prevent transmission, including not shaking hands, hugging or kissing socially and staying home or keeping children home if symptomatic. UPDATE: Trinidad and Tobago provides further advice on how to prevent transmission

On 4 March, Trinidad and Tobago urges public to disregard and avoid sharing all unconfirmed, misleading and/or false information about COVID-19. It also provides advice on personal hygiene measures (hand washing, avoiding face touching, etc.). UPDATE: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago urges public to refrain from sharing unconfirmed or false information and provides hygiene advice

date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: On 4 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Minister of Health gives press conference to address 'epidemic of misinformation, disinformation'. He states that this is known from social media, but is now infecting mainstream media as well and is causing panic in the public, resulting in panic buying of food and masks that creates artificial shortages. He urges the media to be responsible and to work with the government. He states that from 5 March, two press releases will be sent daily on the number of tests that have been performed and the results, and that if there is a positive test, he will call an emergency press conference. UPDATE: On 4 March, Minister of Health gives press conference to address 'epidemic of misinformation, disinformation', urging the media to be responsible and to work with the government. He states that from 5 March, two press releases with status updates will be sent daily.

description: On 11 March, Trinidad and Tobago Minister of Health responds to media reports that a person traveling through T&T tested positive for COVID-19 in Canada. He stresses that there is no evidence to suggest that the traveler contracted the virus in T&T and urges mainstream media to be responsible in way that they report on COVID-19 as it is causing undue fear and panic UPDATE: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago informs public that a news story circulating is not supported by any evidence and urges media to report responsibly on virus

On 11 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces cooperation with WHO and states that there are still no confirmed cases in the country. UPDATE: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago announces cooperation with WHO and states that there are still no confirmed cases in the country.

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago advises public to disregard fake news of multiple COVID-19 cases being circulated on Whatsapp and reminds the public to get updates only from reliable sources. It also informs the public that issuing fake news is punishable with fines or imprisonment. UPDATE: As part of a broader public awareness campaign, Trinidad and Tobago advises public to disregard fake news & only follow reliable sources.
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 24 March, Trinidad and Tobago holds a media briefing in which medical epidemiologist at the Ministry of Health, Dr Avery Hinds, explains to the public the concepts behind contact tracing, how that relates to quarantine and how those procedures limit spread, so that the public understands the basis behind the request to stay at home.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On 25 March, Trinidad and Tobago's Ministry of Health advises the population of a fake news post. It states that members of the public are not authorised to use the official letterhead of the Ministry of Health, in any form, and should refrain from doing so. The public is urged to disregard and avoid sharing all unconfirmed, misleading and/or false information about COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description: On 25 Mar 20, MOH advises population of alleged fake news post and authorised used of the official letterhead of the MOH. For general information specific to Trinidad and Tobago and on Covid-19, public are advised to visit the list of pages from MOH and Ministry of communication.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On 28 Mar 20, MOH advises public about criminals masquerading as public health employees and requesting access to homes, to allegedly take body temperature readings, as part of the national COVID-19 response. 
Public are advised that while the overall management of the spread of COVID-19 does not include home visits by public health employees, officials are required to have official MHO or Regional Health Authority photo identification clearly displayed at all times and presented to resident upon request. 
Public should immediately terminate further contact and contact the police should individual refused to display or present their identification. They may call the relevant public health unit to confirm the identity.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces that  persons returning to T&T are asked to put themselves under self-quarantine for 14 days. There is a fine of $6000 for persons in breach of quarantine orders.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago announces that visiting hours at all public hospitals are now restricted to one session per day (in the afternoon 4pm - 6pm). Patients will only be allowed one visitor however, on-duty staff will be able to use their discretion, on a case by case basis.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
From Sep 2020, MOH Trinidad and Tobago advised on COVID-19 Discharge Criteria for person in home isolation and home quaratine.
1. Person in self-quarantine will be officially discharded 14 days after the day they were exposed to a suspected or a confirmed case of covid-19 once they do not display covid-19 symptoms.
2. There are different criteria for persons in home isolation.
(i) Symptomatic cases: persons in self-isolation at home, who display covid-19 symptms, will be discharged after a minimum of 10 days after they first had symptoms, plus 3 days where they do not, plus an additional 7 days
(ii) Asymptomatic cases: persons in self-isolation at home, who do not display covid-19 symptoms will be discharged after 10 days from the date that swab was taken for the covid-19 test, plus an additional 7 days
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 15 March, Trinidad and Tobago encourages employers to implement remote work policies for employees with children. If that is not possible, employers are encouraged to explore options of shift work, staggered hours of work and/or rostering. Where alternative work arrangements cannot be made, the employee is to be allowed to stay at home with his/her children without being penalized by either disciplinary action or by non-payment of salary.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Trinidad and Tobago announces on April 26th that restrictions placed on hardware stores would be relaxed. According to it, the stores are now allowed to open for half-day from Monday to Saturday.

description:
Trinidad and Tobago outlines a six-step plan to reopen the economy and borders again. The next phase only starts if the previous one was implemented successfully. Below the whole 6 phases are outlined. However, due to the fact that there is still uncertainty regarding the fact whether the next phases are going to be implemented, this policy entry focuses on Phase 1.

Phase 1 (May 11-May 23) allows a slow opening of restaurants, food establishments, and vendors. All other health regulations (distance, mask and closure of non-essential businesses remains in place)

Phase 2 (May 24-June 6) entails a reopening of the country's whole manufacturing sector, public sector construction, and 50% capacity of public transportation will be allowed

Phase 3 (June 7-June 20) whole public service returns to work with flexible times (if possible), private sector construction may resume, capacity of public transportation may be increased to 75%

Phase 4: The reopening of malls and beaches

Phase 5: The reopening of cinemas.

Phase 6: The reopening of the country’s borders.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry),Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry), Takeaway and Delivery only
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Trinidad and Tobago declares an early beginning of the second phase of the country's reopening of the economy after its nationwide COVID-19 lockdown. It was initially planned for May 24th but will now already start on May 21st after a successful implementation of phase 1 and favourable testing results. Phase 2 entails a reopening of auto repair/parts & tyre shops and laundry & dry cleaning services. Furthermore, public transportation will resume to operate at a 50% capability from phase 1. Domestic workers and personal services like spas and barbershops do not experience a reopening yet but the government promises soon changes and the Ministry of Social Development will now give priority to those employed in this sector. In the meantime, the police will control that all of the restrictions are followed. Furthermore, the PM encourages businesses in his speech on May 16th to implement a No Mask/No Service policy.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Starting June 1st 2020, Trinidad and Tobago announces further relaxations of its post-COVID-19 restrictions. Its plans entail: 
- All Retail Businesses will be allowed to reopen but must close at 6 pm.
– The entire public service will be allowed to resume work from Monday. All Managers will be asked to report for duty on June 01, 2020, while other members of staff will be allowed to report for duty on a rotation (every other day).
– Hotels that have outdoor dining facilities will be allowed to serve their guests
– Maxis and taxis will be required to continue operating at 50 per cent capacity.
– Professional service providers can resume work.
– Air transport to Tobago will resume to meet the demand for flights.
– All the activities of the National Lotteries Control Board will resume.
– Gatherings will remain at 5. Funerals will be allowed to have gatherings of 10.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Restriction of business hours (if applicable note the hours of business in text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Police,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Starting June 22nd 2020, Trinidad and Tobago plans to end the public service rotation system. This system was initially designed to limit the spread of COVID-19 but is now no longer considered necessary. Starting on Monday, all employees will be asked to return to work on a full-time basis.

description: Trinidad and Tobago discourages gatherings above 25 persons. All bars to remain closed and no in-house dining for the next 14 days and religious bodies asked to limit gatherings, starting March 16th. In case this discouragement is not sufficient, it threatens to draft legislations.

description:
Trinidad and Tobago announces that houses of worship will be allowed to resume activities from Friday 12 June, 2020 (in a speech by the PM Keith Rowley on June 6th 2020).

The Chief Medical Officer will provide guidelines for the resumption of religious services which will include the need for sanitization and social distancing. Worshippers will be required to wear masks to attend services which should not be longer than one hour.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)

description:
MOH advises the following changes to visiting rules at all public hospitals:
1. There will be one visiting session from 4 - 6 pm daily. There will be no morning visiting session.
2. Adult patients will only be allowed one visitor per day.
3. Only parents or legal guardians will be allowed to visit pediatric patients.
4. Any visitors who exhibit flu-like symptoms will not be allowed on the ward.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 22 Feb 21, Ministry of Sport and Community Development announced that roll-back measure that allow for outdoor recreational sporting activities for groups of no more than 22 persons was officially implemented.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 24 May 21, in the planning of funerals for covid-19 related deaths, family is advised to plan the funeral via telephone, email or other method that does not require face to face contact; staff and visitors are advises to use N95 mask and nitrile gloves, and disposed of properly, and hands washed with soap and water after; the use of hand sanitising stations is mandatory; cleaning staff should be outfitted with appropriate PPE. All funerals are limited to the maximum allowed in the public heath guidelines and people who are sick or who are above 60 years, immunocompromised or with underlying medical conditions should be advised not to attend. No food and drinks should be distributed and direct contact should be avoided. Religious rites should be limited to 30 minutes and crematorium and open-air prye will not be allowed for deaths that are covid-related as indicated in death certificate. The presence of all visitors to all funeral homes must be recorded and contact information taken and maintained for 90 days after the end of the pandemic.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 14 March, Trinidad and Tobago urges public to practice social distancing by: avoiding in-person meetings, keeping unavoidable in-person meetings short in large meeting rooms with 3 feet distance between people and no handshaking, eliminating unnecessary travel and cancelling non-essential gatherings, workshops, etc. and by limiting recreational activities where close contact is likely.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 4 April 20,  MOH Trinidad and Tobago advises the general population that once they are out in public, cloth masks (including handmade masks) should be used as part of the full range of personal protection measures that should be adopted to reduce the spread of COVID-19. 
As previously stated, surgical masks and N95 masks should be left for used by health care workers.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
